discussion.content:
I think the correct answer should be A. In VSS there is no concept of virtual control place, there is the active chassis and the standby: "The VSS active supervisor engine controls both chassis of the VSS. The VSS active supervisor engine runs the Layer 2 and Layer 3 control protocols and manages the switching modules on both chassis."
For the data plane, "The VSS active and VSS standby chassis both perform data traffic forwarding" and "the VSS standby chassis is actively forwarding traffic" .

comments.content: Agree, there is only standby control plane.

questions.question_text: Which option is correct when using VSS to combine two physical switches into one logical switch?

choices.D: Control planes are combined into one virtual control plane.
choices.B: Only one data plane forwards traffic, while the other data plane is on standby.
choices.A: Both data planes forward traffic simultaneously.
choices.C: Both control planes forward traffic simultaneously.

questions.question_text: Which security function is inherent in an Application Centric Infrastructure network?

discussion.content: If there is no contract, inter-EPG communication is disabled by default. so C is correct

choices.A: OSPF stub areas can be thought of as a simple form of summarization
choices.E: The size of an area (the LSDB) will be constrained by the size of the IP MTU
choices.C: An ABR can only exist in two areas - the backbone and one adjacent area
choices.D: Performance issues in the Backbone area can be offset by allowing some traffic to transit a non-backbone area

questions.question_text: From a design perspective which two of the following OSPF statements are most relevant? (Choose two)

discussion.content:
I think A & B

Once the routers become adjacent on the virtual link, Router3.3.3.3 considers itself an area border router (ABR), because it now has a link in Area 0.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/open-shortest-path-first-ospf/47866-ospfdb7.html

questions.question_text: Which of these Layer 2 access designs does not support VLAN extensions?

discussion.content:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Data_Center/DC_Infra2_5/DCInfra_6.html#wp1098258
"The main disadvantages of the loop-free U design is the inability to extend VLANs outside of an access pair"

choices.C: Offer default gateway redundancy by using dual connections from Access switches to redundant Distribution layer switches using a FHRP
choices.B: Provide host-level redundancy by connecting each end device to 2 separate Access switches
choices.D: Include a link between two Access switches to support summarization of routing information from the Access to the Distribution layer
choices.A: Cisco NSF with SSO and redundant supervisors has the most impact on the campus in the Access layer
